options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class gave me a wonderful introduction to learning about weather and the application of some physics principles into the climate system. The discussion of oceans and storm patterns taught me many new wonderful facts that I had never known before. Finally, the discussion of climate change was interesting and truly something I wish every human got to experience.

I learned a lot about the natural systems that affect the way our planet looks and acts and the ways in which life can survive on it. A lot of the topics are related to things that we as humans experience everyday, such as weather, and while there are also topics that are also more removed, like that of deep ocean circulation or plate tectonics, all still felt at least somewhat relevant.
You learn about the atmosphere, the ocean, geological science, and climate change.
Gained a better understanding of systems within our planet that influence weather and other Earth phenomena

I learned about vertical structure of the atmosphere, hydrostatic balance, lapse rates, GH effect, precipitation, clouds, circulation of the atmosphere, Coriolis Force, large scale circulation, storm types, ocean dynamic, El Nino, paleoclimate, and global warming. I learned how to think about atmosphere/oceans/climate in a quantitative way.
Learned some often overlooked features of Earth, including its seasonality, the reasons for winds in the atmosphere and ocean currents, clouds and their formation, and much more.
Mostly the physics of the atmosphere and ocean. This is also applied to climate change, but the main focus is on understanding atmosphere/ocean structure, storms, and circulation.
Learned the basics of atmosphere and ocean systems and dynamics from a physics perspective. Very briefly covered climate.
A shallow but broad-reaching understanding of Earths energy balance and how this manifests in atmospheric, climate, and oceanic processes.
atmospheric and oceanic systems understanding

Thorough knowledge and analysis of the Earth ocean-atmosphere system with comparisons to other planets, and both qualitative and quantitative foundation for explaining the nature and content of how this system works.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments:
The structure of the class was clearly thought out. Every piece seemed to fit together perfectly. The problem sets and tests worked well. Overall the class was great!

The only weakness is that sometimes some of the data can be intimidating when preparing for a test. Professor Lora did a good job emphasizing that data does not need to be memorized, but I personally found it hard to find the balance of taking the lesson from the data without knowing the data. I also would love to know why some of my answers on problem sets were wrong. Instead of individual feedback, the professor could just release an answer key afterward. That would definitely help!

On the whole, this is a very strong classI felt like I learned a lot, and wasn't even challenged that much in the process. Lectures were clear and interesting, especially when they involved board-work; PSETs were helpful and very doable; and exams could be tough and were a bit of a time crunch, but if you studied a decent amount beforehand, you could definitely get a good grade. One weakness involved the textbook, I thinkwe were told to buy a $45  textbook, and while it did track pretty closely with the material throughout the first half of the course, because it didn't add much information, rather simply restated in more (and unnecessary, when it came to PSETs and exams) detail what was covered in lecture, and because it didn't have sections corresponding to the later units, I honestly think I would rather not have spent the money, and probably could have done just as well in the course without it.

This class covers way too much material. I'm an engineering major, and I felt that this class covered way more than any of my engineering classes. The rate at which Professor Lora went through material was astonishing. It felt like he was always rushing, and there was no end to amount of information he wanted to go through. Professor Lora also kept saying that the goal of the class was not to memorize facts, but it definitely felt like we were expected to memorize facts. On the first exam, he asked us to recreate a diagram from memory that he taught for about 15 minutes. The equation sheet on the exams were also incredibly unhelpful. Instead of equations to answer the problems on the exam, there were constants and formulas we never learned and a bunch of other clutter. Sometimes, you had to know arbitrary constants as well, like how much of the Earth is covered in water, so it made you question whether your approach was right in the first place.

There was extensive discussion on the topics of the class, but this also was a weakness as it was hard to know what I should focus on or what were the big ideas to understand when preparing for exams. More emphasis on that would help.

This course could be improved if answer keys were provided for the psets and exams after their due date. Ive found that looking at past answer keys in other stem classes helps me determine what exactly the professor is looking for, and makes it easier to study.
Prof. Lora is a wonderful professor! Lots of interesting topics covered in class.

The class covers a lot of material without going into a lot of the math past algebra which was nice. The content was presented in a relatively digest-able way. I think a weakness of the course was that a lot of the quantitative work was done on a whiteboard but then not posted. Even though I attended most of the lectures, it would have been nice to have a more organized set of class slides/notes.
Answer keys for the problem sets should be provided

Overall, it was quite good. One negative was that the equations were sometimes given in an odd form on the exam (a form different than that given in lecture). Eventually they could be figured out, but it was a little stressful when taking the test. Also, the tests were maybe a touch long, especially towards the beginning of the semester. Otherwise, I thought the class was nice. The information was interesting and Dr. Lora's lectures were all clear and interesting.

Strengths: good intro background
Improvement: textbook reading and posting of slides was unclear and delayed
I thought the virtual whiteboard classes helped to solidify important concepts, and the PowerPoint lecture courses were a little dull at some points

strengths: well-organized, wholistic, brings up relevant current issues
weaknesses: not very engaging

Strengths: pretty thorough instruction, psets applied lecture material very well, exams were fair and reasonable; course was organized well for solid learning
Weaknesses: pressure to turn on cameras and at an early time (9:25 am)
Both: lower-than-usual engagement (allows for more independent learning but less structured learning/less beneficial if greater engagement is desired)

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Everything worked very well during the pandemic. I think this goes for every class, but the structure of office hours is less fruitful over zoom - so that is the one thing that could be improved in general. But from Professor Lora and the TAs, everything was excellent!

This was the only remote class I took this semester that involved synchronous board-work, as opposed to simply lecture slides, and this was massively helpful to keeping me focused and engaged under the online circumstances. Because Professor Lora was actually explaining content while writing it, you were forced to pay attention to both his words and his written notes, and given that he was writing at the same time, I wasn't completely rushing to jot down everything as I was in many lecture-based classes. When the class became more slide-based, particularly towards its end, I definitely noticed that I was less engaged than I had been. On the whole though, this was one of the best online courses I took.
N/A
Recorded lectures were great. Enabled me to go back and watch recordings of lectures in preparing for exams and working on PSETs.

Recorded lectures were great. It allowed me to efficiently plan my time out during hard weeks. Because I could go back and watch lectures, I didn't have to fear that I'd miss important content. Moreover, it allowed me to study for more urgent things coming up. This flexibility was one of the main reasons I was more efficient overall this semester compared to in-person circumstances.
Virtual office hours and recorded lectures were very helpful in getting help.
this course was simply a virtual lecture which wasnt ideal but it worked.
virtual whiteboard worked well for calculations and diagrams

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes! I would definitely recommend this class to everyone! I think the fundamentals learned in this class are extremely interesting and gives a greater understanding of the world we live in.

I would definitely recommend this course, both for those who need to take it for their major and for those who don't. Perhaps it's the environmental scientist in me, but the topics covered were genuinely interesting and teach you a lot about phenomena that people are generally in contact with every day but really don't know much about, when it comes down to it (like weather, for instance). Not to mention, the topics feel pertinent and even necessary, given the changing climate. Furthermore, I would even go so far as to recommend this to those people who fear all things math- and science-related; for a class that fulfills a QR/Sc credit, the computation element of the course is almost remarkably easy. I haven't heard of this class being on anyone's radar as a good science class for non-science people to take, but I would absolutely recommend it for anyone who's trying to get a QR or Sc credit out of the way and also learn some interesting and relevant content along the way.

Unless you have to take this class, I would avoid it. I thought this was going to be a math-heavy class, but that was definitely not the case. The class was way more qualitative than quantitative, and there were too many random facts we had to memorize. Professor Lora also kept telling us to read the textbook, but the textbook was overpriced without a PDF version, so I ended up just not getting one. You probably should get the textbook if you intend to take this class seriously because Professor Lora will go through the material so fast, you won't actually have time to learn it. In the end, you probably can't get worse than a B, but there are also much better classes at Yale that you could take (even for the science requirement).

In a virtual format, I would recommend it to students who have a great interest in these topics. If it was in-person, I think it would have been much easier to learn for people who arent as interested.
Yes!! I found the course to be on the more difficult side, but I really enjoyed it and am happy to understand more about our atmosphere.

Yes, this class really turns the wheels in your head without the headache part because the prereq. for the math portion is just algebra. It got me thinking about how natural processes worked the way they did. Overall, super valuable and interesting knowledge to have.
This should not be treated as a science gut class. Take it for the major or if you're really interested in the material, otherwise it will be challenging.

I would recommend it, especially if you're interested in the atmosphere and oceans. It has a bit of physics and equations involved, but it isn't that bad and there's lots that we learned without math. It was pretty interesting to learn about the things that we see every day (storms, dew point, etc). Dr. Lora was very nice and explains things quite well, so I'd recommend it if it interests you at all.
yes! great for eps majors and nonmajors alike. would recommend for anyone who wants to know what theyre talking about when it comes to climate change!
Yes, particularly to students whose interests would benefit from a holistic understanding of the Earth system
yes. It supplies students with a wide range of surface level knowledge about oceans and atmospheres
Absolutely. It's super informative and gives you greater insight (and perspectives/skills) into a super important Earth system that affects our daily lives and our future climate.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Live lectures that were recorded.
Asynchronous lecture viewing, in person review sessions and office hours for weekly p-sets.
Lectures were recorded so you could go back to them if necessary
Lectures were live and virtual with the option to watch them later.
Live virtual lectures that were also recorded for asynchronous viewing
Office hours and recorded lectures
Synchronous online lectures were also recorded for later viewing
live virtual office hours
Live virtual lecture that was also recorded
